Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A routine audit is scheduled far ahead, leaving ample time to update documentation
Story: I sat at my desk, the hum of the office fading as I stared at the audit checklist. The routine safety audit was still weeks away, but my manager had made it clear—every document needed to be flawless, every standard met. I knew I could get ahead if I started now, but my phone buzzed with a message from Mom: “Can you call tonight? Dad’s been quiet lately.” I remembered how I promised myself to check in more, to be the son who noticed when things weren’t right at home. My parents rarely asked for much, but I could sense the weight in her words. I glanced at the growing stack of reports, feeling the pressure to prove myself as a diligent engineer. Yet, the thought of my parents waiting for my call tugged at me. I wanted to be there for them, to ask if everything was okay, to listen. But the demands of my job pressed in, reminding me of the expectations I couldn’t ignore. My heart pulled in two directions, and I sat there, torn, unsure which role needed me more tonight.
